metadata.title: A history of social psychological reactions to new technology

relevance.topic: Social psychological reactions to new technology
relevance.relevance: The study examines historical reactions to technological changes, focusing on labor displacement and the social psychological impacts of mechanization and automation.

dependent_variables.displaced: Many workers displaced from their jobs due to labor-replacing technologies.
dependent_variables.unemployment_or_underemployment: Workers displaced by automation face unemployment or underemployment.

text_fragments: 'The second problem, job displacement, has been too long ignored by Europe and America.'
'Management needs to see that it is wiser to devise production systems that make use of the flexibility and intelligence of people.'
qualitative_data.narrative_descriptions: The study provides a historical narrative of workers' reactions to technological changes, highlighting phases of labor-saving, labor-enslaving, and labor-replacing technologies.

historical_context.economic_conditions: Industrial Revolution and subsequent technological advancements.
historical_context.institutional_context: Unionism and labor policies addressing job displacement and working conditions.

outcomes.main_findings: Workers historically react against exploitation and job displacement due to technological changes.
outcomes.conclusions: Technological advancements have historically led to labor displacement, and current practices need to address this issue more effectively.
outcomes.long_term_impacts: Potential long-term impacts include increased unemployment and societal challenges if job displacement is not addressed.
